summary: An atheist gave a speech in a park trying to disprove God, and the town drunk who had been radically saved stood up, ate an orange on stage, and asked whether it was sweet or sour — proving you can't deny something you've never personally experienced.
full_text: There was an atheist giving a speech at some park and he was talking for a while and he thought he had pretty much convinced everybody that he was right, that there's no reason to believe in God. When he got finished speaking he said, does anybody have any questions? Right about then a guy in the audience who had been the town drunk, but he had gotten saved — radically saved — and he was sober. He came up to the platform and as he's walking up the man realized, oh you have a question. He said yeah, and he came up and he had an orange in his hand. The ex-drunk is peeling and eating the orange and he gets up on the stage and the man said, well what's your question? He goes, oh just one second, it's not quite done. He eats the last part of his orange and says, okay so my question is this — was the orange I just ate sweet or sour? The guy said, you idiot, how would I know? I've never tasted it. He goes, exactly right. Then how can you tell me that Jesus Christ is a lie when you've never met him? You've never experienced the new life, but I have. You see, this is something you have to experience yourself.

summary: A drunk man fell into an open grave in a cemetery at night and couldn't climb out, then settled into a corner. Later another man fell in and started frantically clawing to get out — until the first man tapped him on the shoulder and said 'you can't get out of here,' and the second man did.
full_text: I remember hearing a story of a man who went to a bar, had too much to drink, and needed to walk home. He decided to do a shortcut through a cemetery. Pitch black, and he was kind of stumbling around anyway. Well there was a hole in the ground for a burial the next day and he fell into it. He was down pretty low and he was struggling, terrified. He thought he got hurt but he didn't get hurt. So he gets up and he's literally trying to claw his way up the side of the hole and he couldn't, he couldn't get out. So finally he just sat in the corner. A little while later another man fell in the same hole. This guy starts clawing and panicking trying to get out, and the first guy taps him on the shoulder in the dark and says, 'You can't get out of here.' And that man did get out. Sometimes all you need is the right motivation.

summary: Pastor Bob describes the moment in the elevator on his wedding day when his wife Becky looked at him and said 'We're married,' and uses that to illustrate how much greater the gift of receiving Christ is.
full_text: You know, the day my wife and I got married, I remember we were in the elevator at the Regency Hotel in San Francisco and she looked at me as we were going up and she said, 'We're married.' And it was like, can you believe it? It's really happened. Can I tell you something? It was great, but that's nothing compared to what God wants to do for you today. He wants to give you a gift that you will never ever resent or reject the rest of your life.

summary: A father and son were driving through the countryside when a bee flew into the car. The boy who had nearly died from a bee sting before panicked, but his father caught the bee, held it, then opened his hand showing the stinger embedded in his own palm — the bee couldn't hurt his son anymore.
full_text: I heard a story years ago of a man and his son who were driving on this warm day out through the countryside. The little boy had already known from earlier in his life — he wasn't that old, maybe six or seven — but his little boy had gotten stung by a bee and had anaphylactic shock and had to be rushed to the hospital. So the boy was terrified of bees. Well a bee flew into the car and the little boy started to panic and scream. The father reached out and grabbed the bee in his hand, held it for a moment, then opened his hand and let the bee fly around the car again. The boy was terrified. But the father held up his palm and showed his son the stinger — it was embedded in his own hand. He said, 'Son, that bee can't hurt you anymore. I took the sting for you.' That's what Christ did on the cross. The sting of death has been removed because He took it for us.

summary: Pastor Bob talks about a friend from his church who was on dialysis and needed a kidney transplant. When the doctor told him he wasn't doing well, the friend said he was doing great because he had Jesus — illustrating that spiritual health transcends physical health.
full_text: I had a friend years ago who attended this church. He had some kidney problems and then he was on dialysis. Without dialysis he would have died, but they were waiting for a kidney to do a transplant. He really needed a healthy kidney and he didn't have one. So they were doing the dialysis and he went to his doctor. I remember he came in and talked to me. I said, well how are you doing? He said, well I'm doing okay. He said, I went to my doctor's this last week and he asked me how I was doing and I told him I'm doing pretty good because I am. And he said, but when I said that to my doctor, he said, no you're not. And my friend told me, the doctor doesn't understand — I have Jesus. My health may be failing, but my soul is doing great.

summary: Pastor Bob recalls talking to a man after the sunrise service who said he wasn't ready to go forward. Bob asked him if he'd go meet Jesus if He were in the next room, and then told him Jesus was right there in that very room — you just have to open the door.
full_text: I was talking to a man after the sunrise service. He said, yeah some people tried to ask me to go forward and I told them I wasn't ready, I didn't want to go. I'm glad you're here. He said, you know, I just don't really have that conviction in my heart. And I said, listen, if God is real, if Christ really died for you, if He's the Son of God and He rose again from the dead, and He could come into your life and change your life and forgive you and make you ready for heaven — if you could know that was true, would you want to receive Him? He goes, well I guess so. I said, so if He was in the next room and I could take you in there and introduce Him to you, would you go meet Him? He goes, yeah. I said, I have good news for you — He's not in the next room. He's in this room. He's right here. You can't see Him, but the fact is you will have questions the rest of your life. Nothing wrong with looking at the evidence, but ultimately the faith that saves is beyond just human intellectual conviction. It requires you to submit yourself as a child.

summary: The true story of Captain Phillips who was captured by Somali pirates in 2009 — he was held captive but the Navy SEALs rescued him. Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate how Christ rescues us from captivity to sin.
full_text: You know, I think about that movie, and maybe you've read the book — Mr. Phillips, remember that true story of Captain Phillips? Back in 2009 he was the captain of that big cargo ship that was captured by the Somali pirates. He was held captive by them and they didn't know what to do but they're trying to get away, but they're being chased by the U.S. Navy. You've got a little problem there. And the Navy SEALs came and rescued him. He was set free. That's a picture of what Christ does for us. We are held captive by sin, by the enemy, and Christ comes as the ultimate rescuer to set us free.

summary: A pastor at an Easter sunrise service waited for the organist to start playing, but the organist had fallen asleep. When they finally woke him up, he jolted awake and accidentally hit all the keys at once — a loud blast that woke everyone up on Easter morning.
full_text: It was years ago now, back when churches used organs. It was a sunrise service at this particular church. The pastor was there and he was waiting for the organist to get into place to start the first song, the anthem for the Easter service. Well, it was early, really early, and the organist had gotten there and sat down at the organ and fallen asleep. The pastor's waiting, the congregation is waiting, and finally somebody goes over and nudges the organist to wake him up. Well, when he jolted awake, his hands and feet hit the keys and the pedals all at once, and this massive blast of sound came out of that organ. It woke everybody up. The pastor said it was the most effective call to worship they ever had on Easter morning.

summary: Pastor Bob was about 15 years old when he gave his life to Christ, and three others in that cabin that night have since passed away. Over 50 years later, his heart's prayer is still to encourage others to make the same decision he made.
full_text: I would not be here today if He wasn't. There were four of us in that cabin — my friend and two adults. All three of them are in heaven. I'm the only one left. But to this day, over 50 years ago now, my heart's prayer is that I would be willing to encourage people with all that is within me to make the decision that I made. I didn't know you could receive Christ. I didn't know how to receive Christ. I considered myself a Christian because of what I believed. But that night He said, 'Have you received Me?' And my life changed forever.

summary: Pastor Bob was a substitute teacher at a junior high and noticed the shyest girl in class who never spoke a word. But on break, he saw her outside with her friends laughing and being completely comfortable — illustrating how people can be different in different environments.
full_text: I was a substitute school teacher before I was a policeman in Placentia and then a pastor, and you get all kinds of assignments. One of my assignments was a junior high school, and I remember this young girl. I was there for a week in this one class and this one girl — she was the shyest girl. She never said a peep in class. She didn't want to talk, she never was saying anything. And then I happened on the break to see her out with her friends, very comfortable, talking, laughing. She was a completely different person. It made me realize that sometimes people just need the right environment to come alive. That's what the church should be — a place where people feel safe enough to be who God made them to be.

summary: A women's retreat speaker kept telling the women, 'No matter what you're going through, don't worry — you'll be dead soon.' Pastor Bob uses this humorous but profound statement to illustrate fixing our hope on eternity rather than temporal circumstances.
full_text: I remember, it's probably 20-some, 25 years ago now, our women came back from a women's retreat. I don't know who the women's speaker was, but I found out this was a phrase she used throughout her weekend of speaking to our women. She would say, no matter what you're going through, don't worry — you'll be dead soon. Thanks! How much should I pay for that counsel? But you know what? She was right. We have high hopes, but we don't always have our hope fixed on the grace to be revealed to us at the revelation of Jesus Christ. Fix your hope completely on what's coming, not on what's happening now.

summary: A Christian woman with a beautiful home hosted Jimmy Carter during his presidential campaign. When a Secret Service agent saw a place setting for the President, the agent sat down and started eating — he didn't realize it wasn't for him. Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate our access to God's presence.
full_text: I heard a true story of a woman. She was a Christian woman, well known. She had a beautiful mansion, very blessed by God financially. It was during the time of Jimmy Carter's campaigning to be president. Jimmy Carter was a born-again Christian and so he looked for Christians who supported him. She hosted a dinner for him at her home. There was a beautiful place setting at the head of the table reserved for the President. Well, one of the Secret Service agents saw this beautiful place setting and sat down and started eating. He didn't realize it wasn't for him — it was for the President! She had to go over and say, excuse me, that seat is reserved. You see, in Christ, we have a reserved place. We're not sneaking in. We're not sitting where we don't belong. God has prepared a place for us, and we have every right to be there.

summary: Thomas Chisholm wrote the hymn 'Great Is Thy Faithfulness' nearly a hundred years ago. It stayed unknown until 1954 when George Beverly Shea introduced it at a Billy Graham crusade in Britain — now one of the most beloved hymns in history.
full_text: Nearly a hundred years ago now, a man by the name of Chisholm wrote these words: 'Great is Thy faithfulness, oh God my Father. There is no shadow of turning with Thee. Thou changest not, Thy compassions they fail not. As Thou hast been, Thou forever will be. Great is Thy faithfulness, great is Thy faithfulness. Morning by morning new mercies I see.' That hymn stayed pretty much unknown until 1954 when George Beverly Shea introduced it at a Billy Graham crusade over in Britain. And now it's one of the most beloved hymns in the world. God's faithfulness doesn't change whether anyone notices or not.

summary: As a young Christian at Calvary Chapel Costa Mesa, Pastor Bob would wait in long lines after services to have a pastor pray for the anointing of the Holy Spirit — illustrating the hunger new believers have for God's power.
full_text: I was at Calvary Chapel Costa Mesa as a young Christian and after the services we would have afterglows, and people would want the anointing of the Holy Spirit or the baptism of the Spirit on their lives. I was one of them. And I remember we would wait in these lines to have one of the pastors on staff pray for us. They'd be up front on the stage or down below the stage, and we'd get in these lines to wait — sometimes 10, 20, 30 people. I didn't know most of them. I'd look around — who's that? I don't know. But we were all hungry. We all wanted more of God. That hunger for God's presence is what keeps you growing as a Christian.

summary: A Muslim who converted to Christianity was asked by his family why he left Islam. He struggled to explain until he said it was like discovering a diamond after living your whole life thinking glass was the most precious thing.
full_text: I remember hearing a story of a Muslim who converted to Christianity. His family and friends were so disturbed. They couldn't understand — why would you become a Christian? You're a Muslim! He tried to explain but he couldn't figure out how to put it into words. Finally he said, well, it's kind of like this. Imagine you lived your whole life and the most precious thing you'd ever seen was a piece of glass. You treasured it. You protected it. Then one day someone showed you a diamond. Once you've seen the diamond, you can never go back to treasuring the glass. That's what happened when I found Jesus. Everything I had before was glass compared to this.

summary: During COVID, a news segment showed a local Christmas lights display as 'all we still have' — featuring Santa, snowmen, reindeer, and the Elf movie character, with no mention of Jesus. Pastor Bob uses this to show how the world has lost the meaning of Christmas.
full_text: I remember they were interviewing some people at a local place that has all the lights, over here in Brea. Eagles Nest, you've probably been there. They were talking about, hey here's one place you can still go to see basically Christmas. And the guy said, 'This is all we have. This is all we still have.' And I was thinking, well, they were showing pictures of what we still have — it was Santa, snowmen, it was reindeer, it was Elf from the movie Elf. That was Frosty, Rudolph. And I'm thinking — that's all we have? There's no mention of Jesus Christ, the reason for the season. The world has lost the meaning entirely, and we as the church need to bring it back.

summary: The old bumper sticker said 'If you don't feel close to God, guess who moved.' Pastor Bob says he used to like it but realized it's not entirely true — sometimes God tests us through seasons of silence, and He hasn't moved at all.
full_text: Some of you are old enough to remember that bumper sticker — I haven't seen it in years. It says, 'If you don't feel close to God, guess who moved.' I remember when I first saw that I kind of liked it. If you don't feel close to God, guess who moved. Now to be honest with you, it's not really appropriate to have that on a bumper sticker to say to the world, because really it's not always true. Sometimes God takes us through seasons where He feels distant, but He hasn't moved. He's testing our faith. The nearness of God is my good, the psalmist says. God is always near. Sometimes the feeling changes, but His presence doesn't.

summary: Emperor Frederick II in the 13th century conducted a cruel experiment where newborn orphans were fed and bathed but never touched or spoken to, to see what language they would naturally speak. The babies all died — proving that human beings cannot survive without love and fellowship.
full_text: Maybe you have heard of this — it's hard to believe this actually happened. In the 13th century, Emperor Frederick II actually did an experiment. The real question was: what will babies speak as far as a language if they're never taught a language? So they took newborn babies — I guess they were orphaned — they put them into sort of an orphanage where they were fed, changed, and bathed, kept safe. But no one ever touched them and no one ever spoke to them. The question, believe it or not, was: I wonder if they'll speak Hebrew or Greek or Latin naturally. You know what happened? They all died. Every single one of them. Human beings cannot survive without love, without touch, without fellowship. That's why God says don't forsake the assembling of yourselves together. We need each other.

summary: A sick little boy in the hospital was given a teacher to occupy his time since doctors thought he was dying. The boy's health completely turned around — he figured they wouldn't send a teacher to a dying boy, so he had hope, and hope saved his life.
full_text: I heard a story years ago of a little boy. They didn't know what was wrong with him but he was getting sicker. He was finally hospitalized and it became pretty apparent to everybody that he's not going to make it. He was going to die, getting weaker and weaker, and they couldn't figure out what was going on inside his body. But at some point, because he wasn't dead yet, some decision was made — they might as well occupy his time. So they sent a teacher in. He was like kindergarten age, and the teacher came in and started spending time with the little boy, teaching him his alphabet, explaining to him how to put words together. And the most incredible thing happened — this little boy's health completely turned around. No medicine, no surgeries, no diagnosis. He just got better and better. When they actually wound up talking to this little boy and said, what happened? It seemed like everything changed when the teacher came in. He said, well, I figured they wouldn't send a teacher to teach a dying boy his letters if he was dying. It was just hope. That little boy had hope, and it saved his life.

summary: A Christian tourist in Israel tried calling sheep using words he heard the shepherd say. One sheep came to him — but the shepherd explained that particular sheep was sick. Sick sheep will follow anyone. Pastor Bob warns that spiritually sick or immature believers are vulnerable to false teaching.
full_text: I remember hearing a story of a guy that went to Israel for the first time. If you've been to Israel you have seen, like I've seen all 20 times that I've gone, shepherds and sheep. There are still shepherds and sheep. This guy who was a Christian and knew his Bible went over there and saw this large herd of sheep and the shepherd over there. So he went over and started calling to these sheep the best he knew how. He had heard the shepherd talk to them and said certain words, and a sheep actually came out from the flock over to this stranger. The shepherd noticed, walked over and said, hey what are you doing? He said, oh, I'm just trying something out. He said, I thought the Bible said they won't follow a stranger, but that sheep came right out. I thought they only listen to the voice of the shepherd. The shepherd said, that's normally true. But that particular sheep is sick. And the sick sheep will follow anyone. That is true — a sick sheep will follow a stranger, will follow somebody they ought not. And not just a sick sheep — a young, immature sheep will do the same. That's why the cults primarily do their evangelism with Christians. They're looking for Christians who don't know their Bibles, who can be easily swayed.

summary: As a new 14-year-old Christian, Pastor Bob signed up for a free magazine from a TV Bible teacher. His youth pastor Gary saw it on the coffee table and recognized it as cult material — protecting young Bob from being led astray by false teaching that sounded authoritative.
full_text: I was a Christian for less than a year. I was in eighth grade, ninth grade — maybe 14, 15 years of age. I'd given my life to Christ and God started changing me on the inside. I started caring about spiritual things, having real respect for the Bible. I still didn't know it very well but I loved the Lord, and so anything that was spiritual, I was open to. That could be dangerous. There was this TV show, and this guy was obviously a mature Christian, like a pastor guy. He was teaching the Bible, talking about the Greek and the Hebrew and all this history stuff. I was like, wow! They offered a magazine — it was free. I thought, they're obviously Christians, they're not even asking for money. I'll sign up for that. So I started getting this magazine delivered to my house. I was reading it, didn't understand it at all, but I was kind of fascinated. I'll never forget a guy named Gary. He was following up on me as a young Christian from our church, a youth pastor. He'd come by the house to spend time with me, asking how I was doing. We were talking and he saw the magazine right there on the coffee table. I was actually kind of proud of it — I've got Christian magazines! He said, so what is that? I said, well, that's the magazine 'Plain Truth' and it's all about the Lord and the Bible. Well, Gary recognized it immediately as cult material and helped me understand the difference between real Bible teaching and something that sounds good but leads you astray.

summary: A group in Pastor Bob's church started reading a book that taught Christians should never ask God for forgiveness since they're already forgiven. They stopped singing certain worship songs and eventually left to form their own church around this one doctrine.
full_text: I remember years ago there was a book written — I won't tell the guy's name because I'm not going to promote the book. He had a radio program and some people in our small church started listening to his radio program, reading his book. And I noticed they stopped singing during certain of the worship songs. I couldn't figure out why. They finally met with me and said, well here's the problem — in that worship song we're asking God to forgive us. I go, yes, that's true. It was actually Phil Wickham's parents who sang the song, 'Oh Lord, forgive me.' A beautiful song. They wouldn't sing it. I said, what's the problem? They said, well, we have come to understand something we didn't know before — we should never ask God to forgive us. I said, what? They said, no, no, we've learned from this guy that we are forgiven and if we ask God to forgive us when we're already forgiven, we're dishonoring God. And then they formed their own little group, their own little church around this doctrine. You see, it's easy to get off base very, very easily within the church, especially when somebody seems to be speaking with authority.

summary: The story of Ruth and Naomi — Naomi lost her husband and both sons, and told Ruth to go back to her people. But Ruth's famous response, 'Where you go I will go,' came because she had watched Naomi worship God through tragedy, and it drew her to faith.
full_text: I think of the story in the Book of Ruth. It's interesting that it's called the Book of Ruth and not the Book of Naomi. Naomi was a Jew from Bethlehem who went with her husband Elimelech to Moab. While they were there, her husband died, and both of her sons died. It's a horrible, sad thing. She changed her name from Naomi, which means pleasant, to Mara, which means bitter. She said, don't call me Naomi, call me Mara, for the Almighty has dealt bitterly with me. But here's what's beautiful — Ruth, her Moabite daughter-in-law, had been watching Naomi worship God through all of that tragedy. And when Naomi said, go back to your people, Ruth gave that famous response: 'Where you go, I will go. Where you lodge, I will lodge. Your people shall be my people, and your God shall be my God.' Faith-filled worship draws others to worship too. Ruth came to faith because she watched Naomi trust God through the worst circumstances imaginable.

summary: The Old Testament priests had to step into the flooding Jordan River before God would part the waters. God didn't separate the waters first — He waited for them to do what they could do, then He did the miracle.
full_text: Think about the priests in the Old Testament. God says, I'm going to separate the waters of the Jordan River so that you can cross. Joshua, with the armies of Israel, you're going to go fight Jericho and take the Promised Land. But the way it's going to work is this: the priests have got to take the Ark of the Covenant, and you're going to have to get your feet wet. You're going to go into that river — and by the way, it was flood time — you're going to trust Me. But I'm not separating the waters until you do what you can do. I'm not asking you to do the miracle. I'm asking you to do what you can do — a few steps of faith. Then I'll move. Jesus reveals Himself to those who step out in faith.

summary: The ten lepers called out to Jesus from a distance asking for mercy, but instead of healing them on the spot, Jesus told them to go show themselves to the priest. As they went — while still leprous — they were healed. They had to obey first, then the miracle came.
full_text: The ten lepers said to Jesus at a distance, 'Son of David, have mercy on us.' They had heard He had healed lepers. He had actually walked over and touched lepers before — 'I am willing, be thou cleansed.' They thought perhaps He'll do that for us. He didn't. He said, 'Go show yourselves to the priest. Offer what Moses requires in the law.' Oh, okay, but we're supposed to do that when we're healed up! Let's go to Jerusalem — that's what Jesus said. And as they went, they were healed. You need to take a step of faith. You want to see God move? He's more than able to move, but He's waiting for you to do what you can do.
